conclusion: The question asks whether the difference in displacement between two objects, A and B, is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from t = 0 to t = t1.
Displacement is calculated as the area under the velocity-time (v-t) graph.
The v-t graph for object A is represented by the upper curve, and the graph for object B is represented by the lower curve.
Both objects are moving in the same direction along a straight line, as indicated by the positive velocity values.
The displacement of an object during a time interval is the area under its v-t graph.
For any given time t, the displacement of object A is the area under its curve from t = 0 to t, and similarly for object B.
The difference in displacement between the two objects at any time t is given by Δs = sA - sB, where sA and sB are the displacements of objects A and B, respectively.
At t = 0, both objects have zero displacement (sA = sB = 0), so the difference in displacement is initially zero (Δs = 0).

As time progresses, the area under the curve for object A grows faster than the area under the curve for object B because the velocity of A is greater than the velocity of B at all times during the interval t = 0 to t1.
This means that Δs (the difference in displacement) is increasing during the interval.
The velocity of both objects changes smoothly (no abrupt jumps or discontinuities in the graph), so the areas under the curves also increase smoothly.
Consequently, the difference in displacement Δs increases continuously during the interval t = 0 to t1.
Yes, the difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from t = 0 to t1.
